### About Me.
I'm a doctoral student in [Sociology at the University of Chicago](http://sociology.uchicago.edu/people/grad_students/AliciaRiley.shtml). I specialize in social demography and social epidemiology. I study how differences in residential environments can contribute to disparities in health and wellbeing. I am currently focused on better understanding the effects of living in an environment of concentrated disadvantage. 

### Current Projects.
As a Predoctoral Trainee at the [Center on Demography and Economics of Aging](http://coa.norc.org//#People/Training/PredocTrainees), and in collaboration with Louise Hawkley and Kathleen Cagney, I am using data from the [National Social Life Health and Aging Project](http://www.norc.org/Research/Projects/Pages/national-social-life-health-and-aging-project.aspx) to see if living in a disadvantaged neighborhood impacts residential relocation decisions in later life and how this may vary by race. 

In collaboration with Forrest Stuart, Grant Buhr and partners at the YMCA [Youth Safety and Violence Prevention Program](http://www.ymcachicago.org/programs/youth-safety-and-violence-prevention), I am studying how adolescents navigate neighborhood violence in the digital age. This project is made possible through funding from the University of Chicago [Urban Health Initiative](http://uhi.uchospitals.edu/).

### Broader Interests.
I have a background in social epidemiology and community health, and much of my past work focused on health issues facing Latino communities in the U.S. and Mexico.

I am also interested in computational methods for analysis of new data sources. For example, I admire the work done by the [Data Science for Social Good](http://dssg.io) team at University of Chicago.
 
###Learn more. 
[Here](http://www.arriley.com/arriley/work.html) are some examples of my past work.

And [my CV](http://www.arriley.com/arriley/cv_files/RileyAlicia_CV_public%20version%20April%202014.pdf).
